description: From Middle French intermittent, from Latin intermittens (“sending between”), from prefix inter- (“among, on”) + mittens (“sending”), from mittere (“to send”).

adjectives.description: intermittent (comparative more intermittent, superlative most intermittent)

entries.meaning: Stopping and starting, occurring, or presenting at intervals; coming after a particular time span.
examples: Synonyms: periodic, periodical, patchy, spasmodic; see also Thesaurus:discontinuous
The day was cloudy with intermittent rain.
Intermittent bugs are most difficult to reproduce.

entries.meaning: (specifically, geology, of a body of water) Existing only for certain seasons; that is, being dry for part of the year.
examples: The area has many intermittent lakes and streams.

entries.meaning: (medicine, dated) An intermittent fever or disease.
examples: Feuers, and especially those that are called intermittents, discontinuing agues, euen naturally at the beginning and their first inuasion, cause vomits: and at the declining, sweats.
